text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

Before HBS, I was a
medical device engineer

at a large medical device
company in Southern California,

specifically working on
sensors and monitoring systems.

So I was building sort
of the user interfaces

that both patients
and clinicians

use when they're in the OR or
the ICU undergoing a procedure.

So I came to HBS to
really understand

what the environment that
people are operating in

on a day-to-day
basis looks like.

Before, I was at a
very narrow scope

when I was working
as an engineer.

And now I feel like
what HBS has given

me is the ability to zoom
out and understand the bigger

context in which both people
and communities and broader

societies are operating in
to better solve that problem.

When I saw an
opportunity on 12twenty,

our career portal here,
to potentially work

for the National Park Service,
it was something that I kept

joking about with my
friends that I would do,

but I wasn't sure if I
would actually apply.

And then what would
happen if I just

did something I
really wanted to do

and worked backwards to see how
that could fit into a career?

So the Summer Fellows program
was an instrumental part

in deciding to take
this internship.

It was an opportunity to work
within this group that basically

does different consulting
projects for different parks

and helps them solve
major business issues.

What I realized working at
the National Park Service

was that I love being
surrounded by mission-driven,
service-oriented people.

That's something that
the federal government

and the National Park Service
in particular is full of,

people that are
really passionate
and care about what they do.

The first place that
I started actually

was talking to ECs who
had graduated the year

before about organizations
they were really excited about.

So one particular EC
who I admired a lot,

she had actually gotten an offer
for the same NPS internship

and ended up working
on a different startup.

She ended up working
at this company that

was super mission-driven,
health care-oriented, had

exciting operator roles that
actually recruited on campus.

So I ended up
applying with them,

having a really great set
of conversations with them
through the interview process.
They were just on 12twenty.

Ended up getting an offer
with them in November.

And I was really
going back and forth

because I was lucky enough to
get an offer with the Leadership
Fellows program here too.

I really had to just
internalize the thing

that I had learned from summer,
which was, "Rhea, you love being
around mission-driven people.

Both of these options
will present that.

But one is a role that you're
going to be excited about

and one is a role that you've
tried and maybe wasn't super
energizing to you."

So once I really sort of
internalized and processed that,

I was able to pick the operating
role and dive head in, and get
really excited about it.
